speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson declares they will not endure insults, as 'carry coals' means to tolerate abuse.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory agrees, adding that if they did, they would be coal-carriers, a lowly job.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He clarifies that if they become angry ('in choler'), they will draw their swords.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory puns on 'draw', suggesting Sampson should draw his neck out of a hangman's collar instead.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boasts that he strikes swiftly when provoked.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory retorts that Sampson is not easily provoked to actually fight.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He claims a Montague dog would provoke him.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory twists his words: to be 'moved' means to run away, while true courage means standing firm.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He insists a Montague dog would make him stand his ground, and he will take the wall (the cleaner, safer path) from any Montague.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says that taking the wall shows weakness, since the weakest are forced to the wall.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He twists this, saying women as 'weaker vessels' are pushed against the wall, so he will push Montague men from the wall and thrust Montague maids to it, with sexual implication.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory reminds him the feud is between the masters and their servants, not the maids.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He dismisses that, vowing to be a tyrant: after fighting the men, he will be 'civil' with the maids by cutting off their heads.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory asks for clarification: 'The heads of the maids?'

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He makes a crude pun: he means either their literal heads or their maidenheads (virginity), leaving the interpretation open.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory concludes that those who feel it will understand the meaning well enough.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boasts that his enemies will feel his strength while he can stand, and he is known to be a sturdy man.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory jokes that if Sampson were fish, he would be poor John, a cheap dried fish, then tells him to draw his sword because Montagues approach.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson says his sword is drawn and he will support Gregory if they quarrel.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory pretends to misunderstand, asking if Sampson means to turn his back and run.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson tells Gregory not to be afraid of him.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory replies that he certainly does not fear Sampson, using 'marry' as a mild oath.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson suggests they keep the law on their side by letting the Montagues start the fight.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says he will scowl as he passes, letting the Montagues respond as they please.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson corrects him, saying they should respond as they dare, and he will insult them by biting his thumb, a gesture of disrespect if they tolerate it.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram directly challenges Sampson, asking if he is insulting them.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson admits he is biting his thumb but avoids saying it is at them.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram repeats his question to force a clear answer.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson checks with Gregory if the law is on their side if he says yes.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory simply says no.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson tells Abram he is not biting his thumb at them, but continues the gesture ambiguously.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory escalates by asking Abram if he wants to fight, moving the exchange toward open conflict.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram denies wanting to quarrel, addressing Sampson with formal 'sir' to show disdain.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson says he will fight if Abram does, claiming his master is as good as Abram's, escalating the confrontation.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram dismissively replies 'No better,' challenging Sampson's claim of equal status.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson responds with 'Well, sir,' a noncommittal but provocative pause before Gregory intervenes.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory urges Sampson to say 'better' because Benvolio, a kinsman of their master, approaches, suggesting backup is near.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Emboldened, Sampson now claims his master is 'better,' directly defying Abram.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram accuses Sampson of lying, a grave insult that demands a fight in this honor culture.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson calls them to draw swords if they are men and reminds Gregory of his 'washing blow'—a slashing strike—prompting the brawl.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio calls them fools and orders them to sheathe their swords, saying they don't understand the consequences, showing his peacekeeping role.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt insults Benvolio as drawn among 'heartless hinds'—cowardly servants—and threatens him with death, revealing his aggressive nature.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio explains he is only keeping peace and urges Tybalt to put away his sword or help separate the fighters.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt scorns the idea of talking peace while armed, declaring he hates peace as much as hell, all Montagues, and Benvolio, then attacks him as a coward.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Hearing the noise, Capulet calls for his long sword, eager to join the fray despite his age.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet mocks his call for a sword, suggesting he needs a crutch instead, highlighting his unsuitability for combat.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet insists on his sword, claiming Old Montague has arrived and is waving his blade to provoke him.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague insults Capulet as a villain and demands to be released to fight, showing the mutual hatred between the families.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: She commands her husband not to move a step to look for an enemy, showing her desire to avoid further conflict.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He asks who reignited this old feud and questions his nephew Benvolio about whether he witnessed the start of the fight.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He reports that servants from both houses were already fighting when he arrived; he tried to separate them, but Tybalt appeared and swung his sword harmlessly, provoking more fighting until the Prince stopped it.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: She asks where Romeo is and expresses relief that he was not involved in the brawl, showing her concern for his safety.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He recounts seeing Romeo early in the morning, walking troubled; Romeo noticed him and hid in the woods, and Benvolio, respecting his mood, avoided him.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He describes Romeo’s recent behavior: adding tears to the morning dew and sighing heavily, then locking himself away from daylight as soon as the sun rises, creating his own darkness.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks Montague if he knows the cause of Romeo’s sadness.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He replies that he does not know the cause and cannot get Romeo to tell him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks whether Montague has pressed Romeo for an explanation.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He says he and others have tried, but Romeo keeps his feelings secret, like a bud eaten by a worm before it can bloom; if they knew the cause, they would gladly help.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He notices Romeo approaching and suggests that Montague and Lady Montague leave so he can try to learn Romeo’s problem.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He hopes Benvolio will succeed in hearing Romeo’s true confession and leaves with Lady Montague.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He greets Romeo with 'Good morning, cousin.'

speaker: ROMEO
content: He expresses surprise that it is still so early in the day.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He tells Romeo that it has only just struck nine o’clock.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He laments that sad hours feel long and asks if that was his father who left quickly.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what sorrow is making Romeo’s time pass slowly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he lacks the thing that, if he had it, would make time fly.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio guesses he is in love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is out—meaning out of love’s favor.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if he is out of love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo clarifies he is out of favor with the woman he loves.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio laments that love seems gentle but proves harsh and cruel in experience.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees, saying blind love still finds its way. He abruptly asks where to eat, then reflects on the brawl, linking it to love’s contradictions—brawling love, loving hate, and oxymorons like heavy lightness and bright smoke. He feels this confusing love but no joy in it, and asks if Benvolio laughs.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says no, he would rather weep.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks why.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says he weeps at Romeo’s emotional suffering.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that is love’s fault. His own grief weighs on him, and Benvolio’s sympathy adds to it. He describes love as a smoke from sighs, a fire in lovers’ eyes when cleared, and a sea fed by tears—a discreet madness, a bitter poison, and a preserving sweetness.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio stops him, saying he will go along and that Romeo wrongs him by leaving like this.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses this, saying he has lost himself and is not truly present.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks him seriously to name the one he loves.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies sarcastically, asking if he should groan while telling him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks Romeo to stop groaning and just tell him who is causing his sadness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He compares his lovesickness to a dying man being asked to make a will, then admits he loves a woman.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He says he guessed correctly that Romeo was in love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He calls Benvolio a good guesser and says the woman he loves is beautiful.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He jokes that a beautiful target is easiest to hit, meaning she should be easy to win over.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says Benvolio is wrong: she is immune to love like the chaste goddess Diana, armed with chastity and unmoved by romantic words, gazes, or riches. Her beauty will die with her, leaving no legacy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks if she has sworn to remain chaste.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He confirms she has, saying her abstinence wastes her beauty by denying it to future generations. Her perfection causes his despair, and her vow makes him feel dead while alive.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He advises Romeo to forget her.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks how he can possibly stop thinking about her.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He suggests looking at other beautiful women.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He argues that comparing others to her would only make her seem more exquisite, like a blind man never forgetting lost sight. Another beauty would just remind him of her, so he cannot be taught to forget.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He vows to prove his advice works or die trying, showing his determination to help.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet says that Montague is under the same penalty to keep the peace, and he thinks it should be easy for men as old as them to do so.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris compliments Capulet as being of honorable reputation and regrets the long feud, then asks again for his answer about marrying Juliet.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet repeats his earlier position: Juliet is not yet fourteen, and he wants to wait two more years before she marries.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris counters that girls younger than Juliet have become happy mothers.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet argues that early marriage ruins young girls. Juliet is his only surviving child and his hope. He tells Paris to woo her and win her heart, because his consent depends on her agreement. He invites Paris to a feast that night where he will see many beautiful young women, including Juliet, and can compare them. He then instructs a servant to deliver invitations.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio advises Romeo to cure his lovesickness for Rosaline by looking at other beautiful women, using metaphors about one fire or pain displacing another.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo sarcastically replies that a plantain leaf is good for a broken shin, mocking Benvolio’s simplistic cure.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what Romeo means by 'that'.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo clarifies he means for a broken shin, continuing his ironic tone.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio questions if Romeo is mad.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is not mad but more confined than a madman—tormented and deprived—then breaks off to greet the servant.

speaker: ROMEO
content: When the servant asks if he can read, Romeo answers bitterly that he can read his own miserable fortune.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he can read if he knows the letters and language.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo reads the invitation list aloud, which includes Rosaline and other Capulets, then asks where these people are going.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if they are going to supper.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks whose house it is.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo admits he should have asked the servant who the party host was earlier.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio tells Romeo that Rosaline, whom he loves, will be at the Capulet feast, and urges him to go and compare her to other beauties so he will realize she is not as special as he thinks. 'Unattainted' means unbiased; 'thy swan a crow' means his beloved will seem ordinary by comparison.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists his eyes are devoted to Rosaline like a religion, and if they are wrong, they should be punished as heretics. He claims the sun has never seen anyone as beautiful as her since the world began, showing his stubborn infatuation.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio argues that Romeo only saw Rosaline as fair because there was no one else to compare her to, and if he weighs her against another girl at the feast, his current favorite will hardly seem the best. 'Scant show well' means she will barely appear attractive.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to go, but only to enjoy the sight of Rosaline, not to see any other woman Benvolio might show him.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks the Nurse to fetch Juliet, then changes her mind and asks her to stay, noting that Juliet is at a suitable age for marriage.

speaker: JULIET
content: She responds to the call, asking who is summoning her.

speaker: JULIET
content: She politely addresses her mother and asks what she wants.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She first dismisses the Nurse for privacy, then recalls her, acknowledging the Nurse’s familiarity with Juliet’s upbringing.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She states that Juliet is not yet fourteen, prompting the Nurse to recall the exact timing.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She confirms the Nurse’s calculation, noting it is a fortnight and some days until Lammas-tide.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She interrupts the Nurse’s rambling story, asking her to be quiet.

speaker: JULIET
content: She echoes her mother’s request, telling the Nurse to stop talking as well.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She shifts the conversation to the topic of marriage, directly asking Juliet her feelings about it.

speaker: JULIET
content: She replies that marriage is an honor she has not yet considered.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She argues that many respected Veronese ladies younger than Juliet are already mothers, and she herself was a mother at Juliet’s age.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She announces that the noble Paris wishes to court Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She urges Juliet to observe Paris at the feast, using an extended metaphor of reading a beautiful book to suggest she will find delight and completeness in him.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks Juliet directly if she can love Paris.

speaker: JULIET
content: She agrees to consider Paris if her looking leads to liking, but will not let her feelings go deeper than her mother approves.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tells the servant they will follow him to the feast.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks whether they should offer a formal excuse for attending the party or just go in without any explanation.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says elaborate introductions are out of fashion; they will not perform a rehearsed prologue but let the hosts judge them as they please, then dance a measure and leave.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks for a torch because he feels heavy-hearted and prefers to carry light rather than dance.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio insists that Romeo must dance.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he has a soul of lead, weighing him down so he cannot move, unlike his nimble-footed friends.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio tells Romeo, as a lover, to borrow Cupid’s wings and rise above ordinary limits.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies that he is too deeply wounded by love’s arrow to fly; he is bound by sorrow and sinks under love’s weight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio quips that if Romeo sinks under love’s burden, he is oppressing love, which is too tender for such weight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo questions whether love is tender, calling it rough, rude, boisterous, and painful like a thorn.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio advises Romeo to fight back against love’s roughness. He then puts on a mask, joking that he doesn’t care if people notice his odd looks—let the frowning onlookers blush instead.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges everyone to enter and start dancing immediately.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo again asks for a torch, saying let the carefree dance; he will follow an old saying and be a spectator, since the fun is not for him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio plays on words: 'dun’s the mouse' means keep still, but if Romeo is stuck (dun) in love’s mire, they’ll pull him out. He says they are wasting time.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo objects that they are not actually burning daylight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio clarifies that by delaying they waste their torchlight needlessly, like lighting lamps by day; he says his true meaning is wiser than it may seem.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo concedes their intention in going to the masque is good, but he still thinks it is unwise.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He asks Romeo why he is reluctant to attend the party, prompting an explanation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He reveals he had a dream last night, hinting at his troubled state of mind.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He claims he also dreamed, setting up a playful exchange about dreams.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks what Mercutio dreamed, continuing their banter.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He puns that dreamers often lie, meaning both tell falsehoods and recline in bed.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He counters that dreams can be true, showing his belief in their significance.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He launches into a fanciful speech about Queen Mab, the fairy who causes dreams by riding in a tiny chariot over sleeping people, making lovers dream of love, courtiers of etiquette, lawyers of fees, ladies of kisses (sometimes punished with blisters for sweet breath), courtiers of favors, parsons of church incomes, and soldiers of battle before they wake frightened. He adds she tangles horses’ manes and maids’ hair, and teaches maids to bear weight, making them women. This speech mocks Romeo’s belief in dreams as mere fantasies.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He interrupts, telling Mercutio to stop talking nonsense, showing his irritation and preoccupation.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He agrees he talks of dreams, which he calls idle brainchildren of vain fantasy, as insubstantial as air and as changeable as the wind that shifts from north to south. This reinforces his view that dreams are meaningless.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He says this talk of wind distracts them, and they will be late for the party, urging them to move on.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He fears they are too early, as he dreads some fateful event starting tonight that will end his life by untimely death, but he resigns to whatever guides his course and urges them forward. This reveals his foreboding about the party.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He calls for the drum to sound, signaling their departure to the Capulet feast.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He welcomes the guests and urges the ladies to dance, joking that any who refuse must have corns on their feet. He nostalgically recalls his own youthful dancing days, then calls for music, more light, and cooler air, noting the unexpected fun.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: He responds to Capulet's question about how long it has been since they last wore masks, saying it was thirty years ago.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He corrects his cousin, insisting it was only twenty-five years ago, at the wedding of Lucentio near Pentecost.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: He insists it was longer, pointing out that Lucentio's son is now thirty years old.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He disputes this, claiming the son was only a ward—a minor under guardianship—two years ago.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks a servant to identify the lady across the room who is touching a knight's hand.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He marvels at Juliet's beauty, saying she outshines the torches and appears like a jewel in dark night or a dove among crows. He resolves to touch her hand after the dance and renounces any past loves, declaring this his first sight of true beauty.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Recognizing Romeo's voice as a Montague, he calls for his rapier, accusing Romeo of coming in disguise to mock their feast. He swears by his family's honor that killing him would be justified.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He asks Tybalt why he is so angry.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He explains that Romeo, their enemy, has come to spite them and scorn their celebration.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He confirms it is young Romeo.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He affirms it is Romeo and calls him a villain.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He urges Tybalt to calm down and leave Romeo alone, praising Romeo as a well-behaved youth of good reputation in Verona. He forbids any insult to a guest in his house and demands Tybalt drop his angry appearance.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He argues that such anger is fitting when a villain is present and says he will not tolerate Romeo.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He angrily insists Romeo will be tolerated, asserting his authority as host. He accuses Tybalt of trying to cause a mutiny and act recklessly—'set cock-a-hoop' means to behave arrogantly or disruptively.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He protests that it is a disgrace to allow Romeo to remain.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet scolds Tybalt for being insolent and warns that his defiant behavior will bring trouble. He calls him a saucy boy and princox (an impertinent youth), ordering him to be quiet or face consequences, then shifts to cheerful hosting, showing his volatile temper and desire to maintain party decorum.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt expresses his rage at being forced to tolerate Romeo's presence, saying enforced patience clashes with his anger, making him tremble. He vows to withdraw now but promises this intrusion will turn from sweet to bitter revenge later, establishing his vengeful character and foreshadowing future conflict.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses Juliet with religious metaphor, calling her hand's touch a profanation of a holy shrine and offering his lips as two blushing pilgrims to smooth the rough touch with a kiss. This begins their flirtatious sonnet exchange, showing his instant infatuation and poetic courtship style.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet playfully counters Romeo's metaphor, saying he undervalues his hand, which shows polite devotion, and notes that saints and pilgrims touch hands, with palm-to-palm contact being a holy palmers' (pilgrims') kiss. She matches his wit while maintaining modesty, extending the religious imagery.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if saints and holy palmers have lips too, cleverly shifting the metaphor to justify kissing.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet replies that pilgrims use lips for prayer, not kissing, continuing the metaphor but setting a pious boundary.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo pleads, 'Then let lips do what hands do'—they pray, so she should grant the prayer lest his faith turns to despair. He uses her religious framework to request a kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says saints do not move, though they grant prayers, meaning she'll stay still but permit the prayer (kiss). This is a coy acceptance within their metaphor.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says then she should not move while he takes the effect of his prayer (kisses her), and claims his sin is purged by her lips. He acts on her permission, completing their sonnet.

speaker: JULIET
content: After the kiss, Juliet remarks that then her lips have the sin they took from him, playfully suggesting the sin transferred to her.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo exclaims at her sweet accusation and asks her to give his sin back (i.e., kiss again), continuing their flirtatious banter.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says 'You kiss by the book,' meaning he kisses expertly, as if following a manual—a compliment with a hint of teasing about his practiced style.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks the Nurse who Juliet's mother is, showing his sudden concern about her family identity.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Learning she is a Capulet, Romeo exclaims in despair that his life is his enemy's debt—his existence now belongs to his foe, revealing the tragic irony of their love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Romeo to leave because the party is at its peak and they should go, trying to avert trouble.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees but says his fear makes him more uneasy, meaning his dread about Juliet being a Capulet increases his inner turmoil.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet insists his guests stay for a light meal, then thanks them as they leave. He calls for more light and announces he is going to bed, noting how late it has grown. This speech marks the party's end and clears the stage for Juliet's private conversation.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks the Nurse to identify a gentleman across the room, showing her immediate interest in Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks about another man leaving, trying to narrow down who caught her attention.

speaker: JULIET
content: She inquires about the man who refused to dance, further pinpointing Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet urgently tells the Nurse to learn his name, adding that if he is married, she will die unmarried—her grave will be her wedding bed. This reveals the depth of her instant attachment.

speaker: JULIET
content: Upon learning he is Romeo Montague, her family's enemy, she exclaims that her only love comes from her only hate. She saw him too early without knowing his identity, and now knows too late. This is a monstrous birth of love, that she must love a despised enemy.

speaker: JULIET
content: When the Nurse questions her words, Juliet dismisses it as a rhyme she learned from her dance partner, hiding her true feelings as they are called away.

speaker: CHORUS
content: The Chorus explains that Romeo's old infatuation with Rosaline is dead, replaced by new love for Juliet. Both are enchanted by appearances, but Romeo must woo his supposed enemy, and Juliet has even fewer chances to meet him. Yet passion gives them power and time provides means to meet, sweetening their extreme difficulties with extreme sweetness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks how he can leave when his heart remains with Juliet. He tells his body to turn back and find its center, meaning his heart, then climbs the wall into the Capulet orchard.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio calls out for Romeo, showing his concern and confusion about his cousin's disappearance.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that Romeo has wisely gone home to bed, using sarcasm to dismiss Benvolio's worry.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio insists Romeo ran this way and jumped the wall, urging Mercutio to call for him again.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mockingly summons Romeo as if by magic, calling him by exaggerated lover's traits and invoking Rosaline's features. He references Cupid and King Cophetua to satirize romantic idealism, concluding that Romeo must be 'dead' to the world and needs conjuring.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that if Romeo hears this mockery, it will anger him, showing his more cautious nature.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio claims his conjuring won't anger Romeo, but conjuring a spirit in his mistress's 'circle' (a sexual pun) would. He insists his invocation is honest and meant only to summon Romeo himself.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio suggests Romeo has hidden among the trees to keep company with the moody night, and that his blind love suits the darkness.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio quips that if love is blind, it can't hit its target. He then makes a series of crude puns about medlar fruit (open-arse) and poperin pear, implying sexual desire. He gives up, saying he'll go to his trundle bed, finding the field too cold.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio agrees they should leave, recognizing it's pointless to search for someone who doesn't want to be found.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo mocks those who joke about pain without experiencing it, then sees Juliet at her window and compares her to the sun, urging her to outshine the moon, which is pale with envy. He tells her to reject the moon's chaste service, symbolized by its sickly green color, and declares his love. He imagines her eyes as stars and her beauty so radiant it would make birds sing at night. He wishes he could touch her cheek like a glove.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet sighs, expressing her inner turmoil.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo hears her and implores her to speak again, comparing her to an angel whose glory amazes mortals gazing up from below.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet wonders why Romeo must be a Montague, asking him to renounce his name or swear his love so she can cease being a Capulet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo debates whether to listen further or speak now.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet reflects that only his name is her enemy, not Romeo himself. She argues a name is arbitrary, using the rose as an example: it would smell as sweet by any other name. She urges him to discard his name and take her in exchange.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to abandon his name and be newly baptized if she calls him her love.

speaker: JULIET
content: Startled, Juliet asks who is hidden in the dark and has overheard her private thoughts.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he cannot identify himself by his hated name, which is an enemy to her, and wishes he could destroy it if written.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet recognizes his voice and asks if he is Romeo the Montague.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is neither if either displeases her.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks how and why he came, noting the high walls and danger of death if her kinsmen find him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says love gave him wings to scale the walls, since stone barriers cannot keep love out, and love dares anything, so her relatives are no obstacle.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet warns that if they see him, they will kill him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies that more danger lies in her angry look than in twenty of their swords; if she looks kindly, he is safe from their hatred.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she would not want them to see him here for anything in the world.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says the darkness conceals him, and he would rather die from his enemies' hatred than live without her love. This shows his reckless devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks how he discovered her location, expressing surprise and perhaps suspicion.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He claims love guided him, and he would travel to the farthest shore for her. This metaphor emphasizes his willingness to take risks.

speaker: JULIET
content: She admits the night hides her blush, and though she wishes she could be more formal, she abandons pretense. She worries she seems too easily won but insists her love is genuine, asking him to speak truthfully. She explains her openness is due to him overhearing her private feelings.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He begins to swear his love by the moon, showing his eagerness to pledge himself.

speaker: JULIET
content: She rejects swearing by the changeable moon, fearing his love might be equally unstable.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks what he should swear by instead, showing his willingness to comply.

speaker: JULIET
content: She tells him not to swear at all, or to swear by himself, whom she worships like a god.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He starts to speak of his heart's love, but she interrupts.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says not to swear, expressing joy but also concern that their vows are too hasty. She compares their love to a bud that needs time to bloom, and bids him good night with a wish for peaceful rest.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He protests, feeling unsatisfied without a formal exchange of vows.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks what satisfaction he wants, prompting him to clarify.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He desires the exchange of faithful vows of love.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she already gave her love before he asked, yet wishes she could give it again.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He questions if she would take it back, concerned about her meaning.

speaker: JULIET
content: She explains she only wishes to give it again freely. Her love is infinite and grows the more she gives. Hearing the Nurse, she hastily promises to return and asks him to be true.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo fears this perfect night is only a dream, too wonderful to be real, showing his disbelief at his sudden happiness.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says if Romeo’s love is honorable and his intent is marriage, he should send word tomorrow about when and where the ceremony will be, and she will entrust her life and fortune to him.

speaker: JULIET
content: Interrupted by the Nurse, she quickly adds that if his intentions are not good, he should stop pursuing her and let her grieve.

speaker: JULIET
content: She promises to send someone to him tomorrow, reinforcing her commitment despite the interruption.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo begins an oath, 'So thrive my soul,' expressing his sincerity, but is cut off.

speaker: JULIET
content: She bids him good night again, emphasizing her reluctance to part.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He laments that parting makes things worse, comparing lovers meeting to schoolboys leaving school joyfully, but parting to schoolboys returning sadly.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet calls Romeo back quietly, wishing she had a falconer’s voice to call him like a trained hawk. She explains her restraint is due to her situation ('bondage is hoarse'), or else she would loudly call his name until Echo grew hoarse.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says his soul is calling his name, and lovers' voices at night sound sweet and musical to listening ears.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says his name tenderly, showing her affection.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He responds affectionately with 'My dear?'

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks what time tomorrow she should send someone to him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He replies 'By the hour of nine,' giving a specific time.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she will not fail and that the wait feels like twenty years, then admits she has forgotten why she called him back.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He offers to stay until she remembers, showing his unwillingness to leave.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she would forget on purpose just to keep him there, remembering how much she loves his company, revealing her desire to prolong their time together.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says he will remain here so that she will keep forgetting any other home but this place with him, showing his desire to stay in her presence and be the only thing she remembers.

speaker: JULIET
content: She notes it is nearly morning and wants him to leave, but only as far as a spoiled child’s pet bird—letting it hop away briefly, then pulling it back with a silk thread, jealous of its freedom. This captures her conflicted feelings between caution and affection.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He wishes he were her bird so he could be close to her and under her control, expressing his longing to stay near her.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she would also like that, but fears she would kill him with too much affection. She bids good night, calling their parting a sweet sorrow, and says she will keep saying good night until morning comes.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He wishes sleep and peace upon her, then wishes he himself were sleep and peace so he could rest sweetly with her. He then says he will go to his confessor Friar Laurence’s cell to seek his help and tell him of his good fortune.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar describes dawn overcoming night, then explains he must gather both poisonous and medicinal plants. He reflects on nature's dual role as womb and tomb, noting everything on earth has some virtue, but even good things can become harmful when misused. This introduces the theme of duality that parallels Romeo's situation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo greets the Friar with 'Good morning'.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar responds with a blessing ('Benedicite') and expresses surprise at Romeo's early arrival. He suggests that only distress or sleeplessness would bring a young person out so early, unlike older men who naturally wake early due to worries.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo confirms he hasn't slept, calling his rest 'sweeter'—hinting at his joyful night.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar asks if Romeo was with Rosaline, assuming his distress is over his previous love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo denies this, saying he has forgotten Rosaline and the sorrow she caused him.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Pleased, the Friar asks where Romeo has been instead.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he's been feasting with his enemy (the Capulets) and that he and Juliet have wounded each other with love. He asks for the Friar's help to heal them both, as he bears no hatred toward his foe.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar urges Romeo to speak plainly, warning that confusing confessions will receive confusing absolution.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo directly states he loves Juliet Capulet and she loves him. He asks the Friar to marry them today, promising to explain how they met later.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is shocked at Romeo's sudden change of affection from Rosaline. He criticizes young men's fickle love based on appearance rather than true feeling. He recalls Romeo's recent tears for Rosaline and concludes that women may fall when men are so inconstant.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo reminds the Friar that he often scolded him for loving Rosaline.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar clarifies he scolded Romeo for obsessive infatuation ('doting'), not for genuine love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo adds that the Friar told him to 'bury' his love.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar explains he meant to bury one love, not to replace it immediately with another.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks not to be scolded, saying Juliet returns his love equally, unlike Rosaline who did not.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says that Rosaline knew Romeo’s love was memorized and insincere, unlike true understanding. He calls Romeo a waverer in affection and agrees to help him, hoping this marriage might end the feud between their families.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges them to leave immediately, saying he is in a hurry.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He advises caution, warning that rushing leads to mistakes.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He wonders where Romeo is and asks if he came home last night.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He says Romeo did not go to his father's house, as he heard from Romeo's servant.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He blames Rosaline's coldness for tormenting Romeo and driving him mad.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He reports that Tybalt, a Capulet relative, sent a letter to Romeo's father's house.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He immediately assumes the letter is a challenge to a duel.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He believes Romeo will respond to the challenge.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jokes that anyone who can write could answer a letter, playing on the word 'answer'.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He clarifies that Romeo will answer Tybalt himself, accepting the dare.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He mocks Romeo as already defeated by love—wounded by Rosaline's glance, a love song, and Cupid's arrow—and doubts he can face Tybalt.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks what kind of fighter Tybalt is.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He describes Tybalt as a master duelist who fights with precision and style, using technical fencing terms like 'passado' and 'punto reverso' to emphasize his skill.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks for clarification, not understanding the fencing jargon.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He complains about affected, fashionable men who use fancy new speech and manners, calling them 'pardon-me's' for their over-politeness.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He announces Romeo's arrival, shifting the scene's focus.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jokes that Romeo looks thin and lovelorn, mocks famous beauties as inferior to Romeo's new love, and greets him in French to tease his fashionable baggy trousers ('slop') and his absence the previous night.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He returns their greeting and asks what 'counterfeit' (deception) Mercutio claims he gave them.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He refers to Romeo’s earlier disappearance as a 'slip' (escape) and asks if Romeo cannot understand the joke.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He apologizes, saying his business was important and in such a situation a man may be excused for being impolite.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He twists Romeo’s words, suggesting that Romeo’s 'case' (situation) forces a man to bend at the knees—implying he was with a woman.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He clarifies that Mercutio means 'to curtsy,' acknowledging the bawdy implication.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He agrees that Romeo has correctly understood his suggestive joke.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He sarcastically calls Mercutio’s explanation very polite.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He boasts that he is the perfect example (the 'pink') of courtesy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He notes that 'pink' can mean a flower, playing on the word.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He confirms Romeo’s interpretation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He extends the pun, saying his shoe (pump) is well decorated with flowers, continuing the bawdy wordplay.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He urges Romeo to keep up the jest until his shoe is worn out, so the joke outlasts the shoe and remains uniquely clever.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He mocks Mercutio’s joke as thin and simple, punning on 'single-soled' (cheap) and 'solely singular' (only unique).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He calls for Benvolio to intervene, pretending his wit is exhausted.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He urges Mercutio to keep going with speed, or he will claim victory in their wit contest.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says if Romeo’s wits lead them on a wild-goose chase (pointless pursuit), he gives up, joking that Romeo has more foolishness in one wit than he has in all five senses.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He retorts that Mercutio was never truly with him in wit, especially when it came to foolishness ('the goose').

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokingly threatens to bite Romeo’s ear as a playful punishment for his jest.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo playfully calls Mercutio a goose and tells him not to bite.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio says Romeo’s wit is like a bitter apple or sharp sauce, meaning it’s clever but harsh.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo turns the insult back, saying such sharp wit is fitting for a sweet goose like Mercutio.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio praises Romeo’s flexible wit, comparing it to cheveril (soft leather) that stretches easily from narrow to broad.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo puns on 'broad,' stretching the joke to call Mercutio a broad (vulgar or foolish) goose.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio says this banter is better than Romeo’s earlier lovesick moaning, praising his return to his true sociable self. He compares lovesickness to a foolish jester running around to hide his bauble (a jester’s stick, with sexual innuendo) in a hole.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio interrupts, telling Mercutio to stop his crude story.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio quips that Benvolio wants him to stop 'against the hair'—against his natural inclination.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio retorts that otherwise Mercutio would have made his story large (long or indecent).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio claims he was actually finished, having reached the whole depth of his tale and intending to end it.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo exclaims 'goodly gear' (fine stuff) and 'a sail, a sail!' as he spots the Nurse approaching like a ship.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio adds 'two, two; a shirt and a smock,' meaning a man and a woman (the Nurse and Peter).

speaker: PETER
content: Peter answers the Nurse’s call with 'Anon' (at once).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks the Nurse, saying Peter should use her fan to hide her face because the fan is prettier.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio returns the Nurse’s greeting with 'God ye good-den' (good evening), teasing her with polite irony.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio crudely jokes that the hour hand of the clock is on the mark of noon, using sexual innuendo to mock Romeo's absence and set a bawdy tone for the scene.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds to the Nurse's question by saying he is a man God made to ruin, playing on her words with self-deprecating wit.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He continues with wordplay, saying that by the time she finds Romeo he will be older, and that he is the youngest of that name only because there is no one worse.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks the Nurse's approval, twisting 'well said' into a pun about the 'worst' being taken well, showing his quick, mocking humor.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio jokes that the Nurse will invite Romeo to supper, punning on 'confidence' as 'conference' and 'endite' as 'indite' (invite), adding to the sexual teasing.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He loudly calls the Nurse a procurer, reinforcing the lewd mockery and highlighting her role as a go-between.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks what Mercutio has found, playing along with the hunting cry 'So ho!' but shifting to a more serious tone.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He answers with a bawdy song comparing an old, gray hare to an undesirable woman, insulting the Nurse as stale and past her prime before inviting Romeo to dinner.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he will follow them, showing his intention to stay and speak privately with the Nurse.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He bids a mocking, repetitive farewell to the Nurse, emphasizing her age and his disrespect before exiting with Benvolio.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo describes Mercutio as a talkative gentleman who says more than he means, defending him lightly while acknowledging his excessive wit.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter claims he saw no one mistreat the Nurse and boasts he would have drawn his weapon if he had, showing empty bravado and comedic cowardice.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks the Nurse to give his greetings to Juliet and begins to swear his intentions, but she interrupts him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He corrects the Nurse's misunderstanding, insisting she listen, and instructs her to have Juliet come to confession where they will be married.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He insists she take payment for her trouble, showing his urgency and gratitude for her role as messenger.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He gives further instructions: his servant will bring a rope ladder to him that night, which he metaphorically calls the conveyance to the height of his joy, and he urges her to be trustworthy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks the Nurse what she has to say, showing his eagerness for news from Juliet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He assures the Nurse that his servant is trustworthy, using the idiom 'true as steel' to mean completely loyal.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He confirms that both 'Romeo' and 'rosemary' start with the letter R, prompting the Nurse to continue her anecdote.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He politely asks the Nurse to give his regards to Juliet, showing his respect and desire to maintain their connection.

speaker: PETER
content: He responds 'Anon,' meaning 'right away,' indicating he is ready to follow the Nurse's orders.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet anxiously waits for the Nurse, who was supposed to return in half an hour. She worries the Nurse might not have met Romeo, then dismisses that idea, blaming her slowness on age. She reflects that love’s messengers should be as fast as thoughts or doves, but the Nurse is slow like old people, who seem heavy and lifeless. This builds tension and contrasts youthful passion with age’s sluggishness.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet notices the Nurse looks sad and advises her to deliver bad news cheerfully or good news without a sour face, since her expression ruins the message. This shows Juliet’s impatience and her focus on the Nurse’s demeanor as a clue to the news.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet impatiently says she wishes she had the Nurse’s news instead of her own bones, and urgently begs her to speak. This highlights her desperation and the comic contrast between Juliet’s emotional urgency and the Nurse’s physical complaints.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet points out the irony that the Nurse claims to be out of breath but has enough breath to say so. She complains that this excuse takes longer than the actual news would, and demands simply whether the news is good or bad, promising to wait for details. This underscores Juliet’s frustration with the Nurse’s delaying tactics.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet dismisses the Nurse’s rambling praise of Romeo’s looks, saying she already knows all that, and urgently asks what he said about their marriage. This shows her single-minded focus on the marriage plans amid the Nurse’s digressions.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet apologizes insincerely for the Nurse’s aches, then insistently asks what her love said. Her quick return to the subject reveals her priorities and the humorous impatience with the Nurse’s dramatics.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is confused by the Nurse’s odd reply asking where her mother is, and repeats the Nurse’s own words back to her in disbelief. This highlights the Nurse’s evasiveness and Juliet’s growing irritation.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet complains about all this fuss and directly asks what Romeo said. Her blunt question cuts through the Nurse’s distractions, showing her determination to get an answer.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet confirms she has permission to go to confession, and after hearing the Nurse’s instructions, she excitedly says she’ll hurry to good fortune and bids the Nurse farewell. Her eagerness contrasts with the earlier tension, showing her joy at the news.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet’s final line expresses her exhilaration and gratitude, reinforcing her swift shift from anxiety to happy anticipation as she prepares to go to the friar.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He prays that heaven will bless this marriage so that future sorrows do not reproach them for it.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He agrees but says no sorrow can outweigh the joy of seeing Juliet; if the Friar marries them, death can do its worst—it's enough that he can call her his.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He warns that intense pleasures end violently, like fire and gunpowder exploding when they meet; even honey can sicken if overindulged. He advises loving moderately, since rushing or delaying love both lead to failure.

speaker: JULIET
content: She greets the Friar respectfully as her spiritual advisor.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says Romeo will thank her on behalf of both of them.

speaker: JULIET
content: She replies that she owes Romeo equal thanks, otherwise his thanks would be excessive.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He tells Juliet that if her joy equals his and she is more skilled at expressing it, she should speak and let her words describe the happiness they both feel in this meeting.

speaker: JULIET
content: She responds that true feeling is richer in substance than in showy words; only poor people count their wealth, but her love is so great she cannot tally half its worth.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges them to come with him to be married quickly, since they must not be alone together until the church has united them.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Mercutio to leave because the hot weather makes people irritable and the Capulets are out, so a fight is likely if they meet.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio compares Benvolio to a man who brags about his sword in a tavern but picks fights over nothing after a drink, implying Benvolio is quick to quarrel.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if he really seems like such a person.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio insists Benvolio is as hot-tempered as anyone in Italy and easily provoked into a bad mood.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what he would quarrel about.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio humorously claims Benvolio would fight over trivial things like a man’s beard, nut-cracking, or a tailor’s fashion choices, accusing him of being obsessed with quarrels despite having been beaten for it.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio retorts that if he were as quarrelsome as Mercutio, anyone could buy the permanent right to his life for a short time, meaning he’d be killed quickly.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Benvolio’s legal term ‘fee simple’ as simple-minded, then notices Tybalt approaching.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that the Capulets are coming.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio dismisses the danger, saying he doesn’t care.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt tells his companions to stay close because he intends to confront them, then greets the group and asks to speak with one of them.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio挑衅地回应，要求提伯尔特把一句话和一击搭配起来，暗示他准备打架。

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says he is ready to fight if Mercutio gives him a reason.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio sarcastically asks if Tybalt can’t find a reason without being given one.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt ignores Mercutio and says he associates with Romeo, using ‘consortest’ to mean keeping company.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio deliberately misunderstands ‘consort’ as meaning a band of minstrels, threatens discord, and brandishes his sword as a ‘fiddlestick’ to make Tybalt dance, escalating the confrontation.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that they are in a public place where everyone can see them, so they should either go somewhere private to discuss their grievances calmly or leave to avoid attention.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio defiantly says that eyes are meant to look, so let them stare; he refuses to move for anyone's convenience.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt dismisses Mercutio, saying peace be with him, and notes that Romeo, the person he is looking for, has arrived.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio sarcastically remarks that Tybalt is mistaken if he thinks Romeo serves him; he suggests Tybalt go to the dueling field and Romeo will follow, so in that sense Tybalt can call him his 'man'.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt addresses Romeo, saying the affection he has for him allows no kinder word than 'villain', directly insulting him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds that his reason for loving Tybalt excuses the anger such an insult would normally provoke; he denies being a villain and bids farewell, implying Tybalt does not truly know him.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt rejects Romeo's excuse for the offenses he believes Romeo has committed and demands that he turn and draw his sword.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists he has never harmed Tybalt and loves him more than Tybalt can understand until he learns the reason; he urges Tybalt, whose Capulet name he values as his own, to be content and avoid conflict.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio exclaims in disgust at Romeo's calm, dishonorable surrender, declaring that a thrust in fencing wins the day; he insults Tybalt as a 'rat-catcher' and challenges him to fight.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt asks what Mercutio wants with him, prompting the confrontation.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Tybalt as the 'King of Cats' and says he intends to take one of his nine lives, thrash the rest, and dares him to draw his sword quickly or risk being struck first.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt accepts the challenge, stating he is ready to fight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges Mercutio to put away his rapier, trying to prevent the duel.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio ignores Romeo and calls for Tybalt to make his fencing attack, initiating their fight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo calls on Benvolio to help disarm them, chastising the men for this shameful brawl and reminding them the Prince has forbidden fighting in Verona's streets; he pleads with both to stop.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio announces he is wounded, curses both the Montague and Capulet houses, and says he is finished; he asks if Tybalt got away unharmed.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks if Mercutio is injured.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He dismisses his wound as a scratch but immediately calls for a surgeon, showing he knows it is serious. 'Marry' is a mild oath.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He tries to reassure Mercutio, saying the injury cannot be too bad.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jokes grimly that the wound is not large but will be fatal, punning on 'grave' meaning serious and a burial place. 'Peppered' means finished; he curses both the Montagues and Capulets and blames Romeo for intervening, which allowed Tybalt to strike under Romeo's arm.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He explains that he meant well by trying to stop the fight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He asks to be taken indoors before fainting, repeats his curse on both houses, and says they have killed him ('worms' meat' means a corpse).

speaker: ROMEO
content: He reflects that Mercutio, a friend and the Prince's relative, was mortally wounded defending him, and that Tybalt—now his cousin by marriage—has slandered him. He blames Juliet's beauty for making him soft and less brave.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He announces Mercutio's death, saying his noble spirit has ascended to the sky too soon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He declares that this day's tragic fate will affect many future days, and this is only the beginning of sorrows that others will finish.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He warns that Tybalt is returning angrily.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He resolves to abandon gentle restraint and let fury guide him. He tells Tybalt to take back the insult 'villain,' saying Mercutio's soul is waiting for Tybalt's to join it, so one or both of them must die.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He calls Romeo a wretched boy who kept company with Mercutio and says he will join him in death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says their fight will decide the matter.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He urges Romeo to flee because the citizens are alerted and Tybalt is dead; he warns that the Prince will sentence Romeo to death if caught.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He laments that he is the plaything of cruel fate.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks why Romeo is still lingering.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio points out Tybalt's body, identifying him as the one slain by Romeo, who in turn had killed the Prince's relative Mercutio.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He offers to reveal the unfortunate course of the deadly fight, again noting Tybalt's death at Romeo's hands and Tybalt's own slaying of Mercutio.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She laments Tybalt's death as her cousin and nephew, appealing to the Prince for justice by demanding a Montague life in return, heightening the tension with her grief and call for revenge.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He recounts the fight: Romeo tried to calm Tybalt and reminded him how trivial the quarrel was, but Tybalt, filled with unruly anger, instead fought Mercutio. Romeo intervened, but Tybalt fatally stabbed Mercutio under Romeo's arm, fled, returned, and was then slain by a vengeful Romeo in a swift duel. Benvolio swears this is true.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She dismisses Benvolio's account as biased because he is a Montague relative, falsely claims many Montagues fought, and insists Romeo must be executed for killing Tybalt, pressing the Prince for severe punishment.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He defends Romeo, arguing that Romeo was Mercutio's friend and that his killing of Tybalt merely carried out what the law would have done—executed Tybalt for Mercutio's murder—thus pleading for leniency.

speaker: JULIET
content: She urgently calls for night to come so she can be with Romeo, imagining lovers can see by their own beauty or love’s blindness suits the dark. She asks night to teach her to lose her virginity modestly and hide her blushing cheeks until love grows bold. She envisions Romeo as a bright star in the night, making heaven so beautiful that the world would prefer night to day. She feels she has bought love’s mansion but not possessed it, comparing her impatience to a child with new clothes before a festival.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks the Nurse for news and if she has brought the ropes Romeo requested.

speaker: JULIET
content: She expresses distress at the Nurse’s anguish and asks why she is wringing her hands.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks if heaven could be so envious, then demands whether Romeo has killed himself, saying a simple 'Ay' would poison her. She insists brief sounds will decide her joy or misery.

speaker: JULIET
content: She wishes her heart to break and her eyes never to see freedom again, telling her body to return to earth and lie with Romeo in death.

speaker: JULIET
content: She questions the contradictory news, asking if Romeo is slain and Tybalt dead—her dear cousin and dearer husband. She says if both are gone, it is like the end of the world.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks in horror if Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood.

speaker: JULIET
content: She condemns Romeo’s deceptive appearance, calling him a serpent heart with a flowering face, a beautiful tyrant, and a damned saint. She wonders how a fiend could dwell in such sweet flesh, like a vile book in a gorgeous binding.

speaker: JULIET
content: She curses the Nurse for wishing shame on Romeo, saying shame is ashamed to sit on his brow, which is a throne for honor. She regrets chiding him.

speaker: JULIET
content: She defends Romeo as her husband and reasons that Tybalt would have killed him. She calls back her tears, realizing her husband lives and Tybalt is dead, which is comfort—but then remembers Romeo’s banishment, which is worse than ten thousand Tybalts’ deaths. She says that word means all—father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet—are dead, with no limit to that woe.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says her parents can weep for Tybalt, but her tears will be for Romeo’s exile. She laments that the ropes meant to bring Romeo to her bed are useless, and she will die a maiden widow, with death taking her virginity.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks the Nurse to find Romeo, give him a ring, and bid him come for a last farewell.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He calls Romeo out, saying misfortune is in love with his qualities and he is married to disaster, establishing Romeo's tragic nature.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He anxiously asks what the Prince's judgment is and what new sorrow awaits him, showing his dread of the consequences for killing Tybalt.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He chides Romeo for being too acquainted with sorrow, then says he brings news of the Prince's sentence.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He fears the worst, asking if the judgment is doomsday itself, revealing his expectation of death.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He reveals the Prince's milder sentence: banishment instead of execution, which he sees as mercy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He reacts with horror, pleading for death instead, arguing exile is more terrifying than execution.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He confirms the banishment and urges patience, noting the world is large, trying to offer perspective.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He insists there is no world outside Verona, only torture and hell; banishment is death misnamed, and the Friar's mercy feels like a cruel murder.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He scolds Romeo's ingratitude, explaining the Prince showed mercy by changing the lawful death sentence to banishment, which Romeo fails to see.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He argues banishment is torture, not mercy, since heaven is where Juliet lives; even flies can touch her, but he cannot. He accuses the Friar of using 'banished' like a weapon, asking how a holy man can torment him so.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He calls Romeo a foolish madman and asks to speak, attempting to regain control of the conversation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He anticipates the Friar will speak of banishment again, showing his fixation and despair.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He offers philosophy as armor against adversity, intending to comfort Romeo despite his banishment.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He dismisses philosophy unless it can create Juliet or undo his fate, rejecting abstract comfort in his concrete despair.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He remarks that madmen do not listen, expressing frustration at Romeo's refusal to hear reason.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He retorts that wise men lack eyes, implying the Friar fails to see his true suffering, continuing their clash of perspectives.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: I want to discuss your situation with you.

speaker: ROMEO
content: You cannot speak about something you don't experience. If you were young like me, newly married to Juliet, had murdered Tybalt, were lovesick and banished like me, then you could speak, then you could tear your hair and collapse on the ground as I do now, measuring the depth of a grave that will be dug for me.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Get up; someone is knocking. Good Romeo, hide yourself.

speaker: ROMEO
content: I won't, unless my heartbroken groans wrap me in mist to hide me from being seen.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Listen to how they knock!—Who's there?—Romeo, get up, you will be captured.—Wait a moment.—Stand up.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Run to my study.—Soon.—God's will, what foolishness is this.—I'm coming, I'm coming.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Who knocks so loudly? Where do you come from, what do you want?

speaker: ROMEO
content: Nurse.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Were you speaking of Juliet? How is she? Doesn't she think I am a hardened murderer, now that I have stained the innocence of our joy with blood nearly related to her own? Where is she? How is she? And what does my secret wife say about our ruined love?

speaker: ROMEO
content: As if that name, fired like a bullet from a gun, murdered her, just as that name's cursed hand murdered her relative. Oh, tell me, Friar, in what vile part of my body does my name reside? Tell me, so I may destroy that hateful dwelling.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Stop your desperate hand. Are you a man? Your appearance says you are, but your tears are womanly and your wild actions show the irrational rage of a beast. You are an unseemly woman in a man's body and an ill-suited beast in both! You have astonished me. I thought you were better tempered. Have you killed Tybalt? Will you kill yourself? And kill your lady who lives through you, by committing a damned act of self-hatred? Why do you curse your birth, heaven, and earth? Since birth, heaven, and earth all come together in you, which you would lose all at once. Shame on you, you disgrace your body, your love, and your intelligence. You have all these in abundance but use none of them properly. Your noble body is just a wax figure, lacking a man's courage; your sworn love is empty perjury, killing the love you vowed to cherish; your intelligence, which should enhance your body and love, is misused in guiding both, like gunpowder in an unskilled soldier's flask set on fire by your own ignorance, and you are destroyed by your own defense. Wake up, man! Your Juliet is alive, for whom you were just now wishing to die—that makes you fortunate. Tybalt would have killed you, but you killed him—that makes you fortunate. The law that threatened death becomes your friend and exiles you instead—that makes you fortunate. A pack of blessings falls on your back; happiness courts you in her finest clothes; but like a misshapen and sulky girl, you reject your fortune and your love. Beware, for such people die miserable. Go to your love as planned, climb to her room, go and comfort her. But do not stay until the watch is set, for then you cannot escape to Mantua, where you will live until we can find a time to announce your marriage, reconcile your families, beg the Prince's pardon, and call you back with infinitely more joy than you left in sorrow. Go ahead, Nurse. Give my regards to your lady and tell her to hurry everyone in the house to bed, which heavy sorrow makes them ready for. Romeo is coming.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Do that, and tell my sweet to get ready to scold me.

speaker: ROMEO
content: How much my spirits are revived by this.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Go now, good night, and your situation is this: either leave before the watch is set, or by daybreak in disguise. Stay in Mantua. I will find your servant, and he will inform you from time to time of every good thing that happens here. Give me your hand; it's late; farewell; good night.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Except that a joy beyond joy calls me away, it would be a grief to part with you so briefly. Farewell.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet explains that unfortunate events have prevented him from discussing Paris's proposal with Juliet. He notes her deep grief for Tybalt, whom they both loved, and accepts death as inevitable. He says it's too late for her to come down tonight, and he would have gone to bed earlier if not for Paris's visit.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris acknowledges that this sorrowful time is not right for courtship. He bids Lady Capulet good night and asks her to give his regards to Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She promises to find out Juliet's feelings tomorrow, explaining that Juliet is currently shut away with her grief.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet boldly offers Juliet's love to Paris, confident she will obey him. He tells his wife to inform Juliet of Paris's love before bed and to prepare her for marriage next Wednesday, then pauses to check the current day.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris replies that it is Monday.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Amused by the short timeline, Capulet changes the wedding to Thursday. He asks if Paris approves of the haste and plans a small celebration to avoid seeming disrespectful after Tybalt's recent death, then confirms Thursday as the date.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris eagerly wishes Thursday were tomorrow, showing his strong desire to marry Juliet quickly.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet finalizes Thursday for the wedding and instructs his wife to prepare Juliet. He bids Paris farewell, calls for light, and humorously notes how late it is, saying they might soon call it early. This hasty planning contrasts with Juliet's secret marriage to Romeo, heightening dramatic tension.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet insists it is still night, claiming the bird they heard was a nightingale, which sings at night, not the lark that heralds dawn. She urges Romeo to stay, showing her desperation to prolong their time together.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo corrects her, pointing to the dawn light in the east and describing daybreak poetically. He states he must leave to survive, as staying means death if caught.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet denies it is daylight, suggesting it is a meteor guiding his way. She again pleads for him to stay, refusing to accept the danger.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo declares he is willing to die if Juliet wishes it, denying the signs of morning and calling the light a reflection of the moon. He says his desire to stay outweighs his need to flee, embracing death at her will.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet now admits it is day and the lark, whose song she calls harsh because it separates them. She references a myth about the lark and toad swapping eyes, wishing they had swapped voices too. She urgently tells Romeo to flee as it grows lighter.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo laments that as the light increases, their sorrows grow darker.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet responds to the Nurse's call.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet acknowledges the Nurse's warning that her mother is coming and day has arrived, urging caution.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo bids farewell with a kiss and begins to climb down from the balcony.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet expresses anguish at his departure, using multiple terms of endearment. She says she will need constant updates, feeling time will drag without him, and fears growing old before they reunite.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo promises to send messages whenever possible.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet anxiously asks if they will ever meet again.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo assures her they will, and their current troubles will become stories for their future.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she has a foreboding soul and envisions him pale as if dead in a tomb, fearing her eyesight or his pallor presages doom.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says she also looks pale, attributing it to sorrow draining their vitality, and bids farewell again.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet addresses Fortune, calling it fickle, and pleads that if it is changeable, it should not keep a faithful man like Romeo away long but return him to her soon.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She calls from offstage to see if Juliet is awake.

speaker: JULIET
content: She wonders why her mother is visiting at this unusual hour, since 'procures her hither' means brings her here.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks what is wrong with Juliet.

speaker: JULIET
content: She claims she is unwell.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She assumes Juliet is still crying over Tybalt's death, saying excessive grief is foolish since it cannot bring him back; 'have done' means stop, and 'want of wit' means lack of sense.

speaker: JULIET
content: She insists on weeping for a loss she feels deeply.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says Juliet feels the loss, but not the friend she mourns, implying her grief is misdirected.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says feeling the loss so strongly makes her weep for Tybalt constantly.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She claims Juliet weeps not for Tybalt but because Romeo, who killed him, still lives.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks which villain her mother means.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She identifies the villain as Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says Romeo is far from a villain, pardons him with all her heart, yet admits he grieves her heart deeply, speaking with tragic double meaning.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She insists Romeo's survival is the cause of Juliet's grief.

speaker: JULIET
content: She ambiguously says she wishes she alone could avenge Tybalt's death, hiding her true loyalty to Romeo.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She promises vengeance, saying she will send someone to Mantua to poison Romeo, the 'runagate' meaning fugitive, with an 'unaccustom'd dram' meaning a surprising dose of poison, so he joins Tybalt in death.

speaker: JULIET
content: She deceptively agrees, saying she won't be satisfied until she sees Romeo dead, and would gladly temper—meaning mix—the poison herself. She claims her heart abhors hearing his name and she wishes to 'wreak' (avenge) her love for Tybalt upon Romeo's body, while secretly meaning the opposite.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She promises to find someone to carry out revenge if Juliet finds a method, then shifts to announcing happy news.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says joy is welcome in this difficult time and politely asks her mother to share the news.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She praises Capulet for arranging a sudden wedding to cheer Juliet up, a surprise to them both.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks eagerly which day the event will occur.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She reveals that Paris will marry Juliet at Saint Peter’s Church on Thursday morning.

speaker: JULIET
content: She swears she will not marry Paris, objects to the rush, and declares she would rather marry Romeo—whom she pretends to hate—than Paris. This dramatic irony conceals her secret marriage.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tells Juliet to deliver her refusal directly to Capulet and see how he reacts.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He uses an extended metaphor comparing Juliet’s tears to a storm-tossed ship, then asks if Lady Capulet has told her about the wedding.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She confirms Juliet refuses the match and spitefully wishes her dead.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He demands clarification, incredulous that Juliet isn’t grateful for the match with Paris.

speaker: JULIET
content: She insists she is thankful but cannot be proud of something she hates, even if it was meant lovingly.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He angrily dismisses her reasoning, calls her spoiled, and orders her to prepare for the wedding or be dragged there. He insults her as pale and sickly.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She exclaims in shock at his rage.

speaker: JULIET
content: She kneels and begs him to listen to her.

speaker: CAPULET
