content: He furiously commands her to obey, says his hand itches to strike her, and laments that their only child is a curse.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He calls her a worthless creature, showing his complete rejection.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He exclaims in frustration, using an archaic oath 'God ye good-en' (God give you good evening), then immediately silences the Nurse.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He tells the Nurse to be quiet, calling her a fool whose serious talk belongs with gossips over drinks, not here.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tries to calm him, saying he is too angry.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He angrily explains he has worked constantly to arrange a good marriage for Juliet with Paris, a noble and worthy man, and is enraged that she refuses. He threatens to disown her if she won't obey, telling her to decide by Thursday.

speaker: JULIET
content: She appeals to heaven for pity and begs her mother to delay the marriage or else let her die and be buried with Tybalt.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She coldly refuses to help or speak further, telling Juliet to do as she wishes and abandoning her.

speaker: JULIET
content: She turns to the Nurse in despair, saying her husband Romeo is alive and her vows are in heaven, so how can she remarry unless he dies. She asks for comfort and advice.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks if the Nurse has any comforting words.

speaker: JULIET
content: She repeats her plea for comfort.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks the Nurse if she is speaking sincerely from her heart.

speaker: JULIET
content: After the Nurse's betrayal, she sarcastically says she is much comforted, sends the Nurse away, and resolves to see Friar Lawrence for help or else kill herself.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He expresses surprise that the wedding is scheduled for Thursday, noting the short timeframe.

speaker: PARIS
content: He explains that Capulet insists on this haste, and he himself is not reluctant to delay it.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He points out that Paris doesn't know Juliet's feelings and calls the situation irregular and troubling.

speaker: PARIS
content: He says Juliet is grieving excessively for Tybalt, so he hasn't pressed his suit, as love doesn't flourish amid sorrow. Capulet believes letting her mourn alone is dangerous, so he arranges the marriage to distract her with company.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: In an aside, he wishes he didn't know the real reason to delay the wedding, then announces Juliet's arrival.

speaker: PARIS
content: He greets Juliet warmly as his future wife.

speaker: JULIET
content: She replies with cautious ambiguity, saying she might be his wife if she ever becomes one.

speaker: PARIS
content: He insists it is certain and will happen on Thursday.

speaker: JULIET
content: She responds with resigned fatalism, accepting what is destined.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He dryly comments that her statement is an undeniable truth.

speaker: PARIS
content: He asks if she has come to confess to the Friar.

speaker: JULIET
content: She evades by saying that to answer she would have to confess her feelings to Paris.

speaker: PARIS
content: He urges her not to deny to the Friar that she loves him.

speaker: JULIET
content: She twists his words, saying she will confess she loves the Friar.

speaker: PARIS
content: He insists she will surely confess her love for him.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says if she does confess love for Paris, it would be more valuable said behind his back than to his face, implying insincerity or reluctance.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris observes that Juliet's face is disfigured by her tears.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet replies that her tears have not worsened her appearance, since it was already bad before they fell.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris says her words insult her face more than her tears do.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet argues that truth cannot be slander, and she was speaking about her own face.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris claims her face belongs to him now, so she has slandered it.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet concedes he may be right, since her face is no longer her own, then asks Friar Lawrence if he is free to speak.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence says he is available and asks Paris to leave them alone.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris agrees not to interrupt, reminds Juliet he will wake her early on Thursday for their wedding, and bids farewell with a kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet urgently asks the Friar to shut the door and join her in despair, feeling beyond hope or remedy.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence says he already knows her distress about being forced to marry Paris on Thursday, and it overwhelms his ability to think.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet demands a solution, threatening to kill herself with a knife if he cannot help. She vows death before betraying Romeo, insisting the Friar advise her immediately or watch her die.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence stops her and proposes a desperate hope: if she is willing to die, she might instead undergo a death-like trance to escape the marriage.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet passionately declares she would face any terrifying ordeal—leaping from towers, hiding with serpents or corpses—rather than marry Paris, to remain faithful to Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He instructs her to agree to the wedding, then drink a potion that will mimic death for 42 hours. She will be laid in the Capulet tomb, where Romeo will rescue her upon waking.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet eagerly asks for the potion, dismissing any fear.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges her to be strong, promises to send word to Romeo, and bids her farewell.

speaker: JULIET
content: She prays for love to give her courage, and that courage will provide the means to endure. She bids a final farewell to her father, knowing she may not see him again, which heightens the emotional stakes of her impending risky action.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He orders the servant to invite all the guests listed and then addresses another servant, calling him 'Sirrah' (a term for a male servant) to hire twenty skilled cooks.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He asks how the servant can test the cooks, showing his practical concern for the wedding preparations.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He dismisses the servant, then worries they will be poorly prepared and asks if Juliet has gone to Friar Lawrence.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He hopes the Friar may help Juliet, then calls her a stubborn, willful girl (harlotry here means a mischievous girl) as she enters.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He addresses Juliet as headstrong and asks where she has been wandering about.

speaker: JULIET
content: She deceptively says she has learned to repent disobeying her father's commands and has been ordered by Friar Lawrence to beg his pardon, promising future obedience.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Overjoyed, he immediately sends for County Paris and declares the marriage will happen tomorrow morning.

speaker: JULIET
content: She falsely claims she met Paris at the Friar's cell and gave him appropriate signs of love without exceeding modesty.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He expresses delight, asks to see Paris, and praises Friar Lawrence, saying the whole city is indebted to him.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks the Nurse to come to her room to help choose what ornaments she will need for the next day.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She objects, saying there is time until Thursday, but Capulet overrules her.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He tells the Nurse to go with Juliet and confirms they will go to church tomorrow.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She worries they will be short on provisions since it is nearly night.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He dismisses her concern, promises to manage everything, tells her to help Juliet dress, and says he will stay up to prepare Paris for tomorrow, feeling light-hearted because Juliet has been reclaimed from her waywardness.

speaker: JULIET
content: She agrees the wedding clothes are fine but asks the Nurse to leave her alone tonight, explaining she needs to pray to heaven for help because her situation is troubled and sinful.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She interrupts to ask if Juliet is busy and if she needs any assistance.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says they have already gathered what is needed for tomorrow and asks to be left alone, suggesting the Nurse help her mother with the sudden wedding preparations.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She bids Juliet good night and tells her to go to bed and rest because she needs it.

speaker: JULIET
content: Alone, she expresses terror about taking the potion, fearing it might not work, be poison, or cause her to wake too early in the tomb and go mad from the horror, smells, and ghosts—especially Tybalt’s—before resolving to drink for Romeo.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She instructs the Nurse to take keys and fetch more spices, showing the busy preparations for the wedding feast.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He urges everyone to hurry, noting the rooster has crowed and it is three in the morning; he tells Angelica (the Nurse) to prepare the baked meats and not worry about expense.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He dismisses his wife’s concern, saying he has stayed up all night before for smaller reasons and never gotten sick.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She teases that he used to chase women (mouse-hunt) but she will prevent him from staying out late like that now.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He calls his wife a jealous woman (jealous-hood) as servants enter with cooking supplies.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He tells the servant to hurry and fetch drier logs, and to ask Peter for their location.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He praises the servant’s wit, then notes it is daybreak and Paris will arrive soon with music; he calls the Nurse to wake and dress Juliet, saying he will talk to Paris and urging haste.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks what the noise is about, showing her initial confusion upon entering the scene.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She repeats her question about what is happening, growing more alarmed by the Nurse's distress.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She cries out in grief, urging Juliet to wake up or else she will die too, and calls for help.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He impatiently calls for Juliet to be brought out, unaware she is dead and thinking Paris has arrived.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She echoes the Nurse's cry, lamenting repeatedly that Juliet is dead.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He examines Juliet and confirms she is cold and stiff, using a metaphor of frost killing a flower to express how death has taken her too soon.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She exclaims again in sorrow, calling the time woeful.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He says grief has stolen his ability to speak, personifying Death as silencing him.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He arrives and asks if the bride is ready for the wedding, unaware of the situation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He bitterly replies that she is ready but will not return, saying Death has lain with and deflowered her, making Death his heir and son-in-law.

speaker: PARIS
content: He expresses his shock and disappointment, having looked forward to his wedding morning only to find tragedy.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She curses the day as miserable and accursed, lamenting that cruel death has taken her only source of joy and solace.

speaker: PARIS
content: He feels deceived and wronged by death, crying out that what remains is not life but love in death.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He lists his sufferings and asks why this unhappy time has ruined the wedding, saying his joys are buried with his child.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He scolds them for their excessive grief, arguing that Juliet is now in heaven and they should rejoice she died pure and young. He tells them to dry their tears, adorn her body with rosemary, and carry her to church as custom dictates.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He observes how all their wedding preparations have turned into funeral arrangements: instruments become bells, cheer becomes a burial feast, hymns become dirges, and flowers adorn a corpse.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He instructs everyone to follow Juliet's body to the grave, warning that the heavens frown upon them for some wrong and they should not oppose divine will by further mourning. This provides solemn closure to the mourning scene and clears the stage for the comic relief that follows.

speaker: PETER
content: He urgently asks the musicians to play 'Heart's ease,' a cheerful tune, saying it's necessary for his survival since his heart is heavy with sorrow.

speaker: PETER
content: He explains he wants a merry dump—a contradiction since 'dump' meant a sad song—to comfort him, showing his confused emotional state.

speaker: PETER
content: He bluntly confirms their refusal to play.

speaker: PETER
content: He threatens to punish them soundly for their refusal.

speaker: PETER
content: He clarifies he won't pay money but will give them the gleek—a jest or trick—and call them minstrels insultingly.

speaker: PETER
content: He escalates his threat, saying he'll hit them with a dagger and won't tolerate their crotchets (whims or quarter-notes in music). He puns on musical notes 're' and 'fa,' meaning he'll attack them.

speaker: PETER
content: He sheathes his dagger and promises to outwit them instead, quoting a ballad about music soothing grief, then questioning why it calls music's sound 'silver.'

speaker: PETER
content: He dismisses the first musician's answer as prates (idle talk) and asks another for his explanation.

speaker: PETER
content: He similarly rejects the second musician's answer and questions the third, who admits he doesn't know.

speaker: PETER
content: He sarcastically excuses the third musician for being a singer rather than a thinker, then offers his own punchline: musicians have no gold, only silver, for their playing. He completes the quoted verse to mock their mercenary motives.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo feels optimistic because his dreams suggest good news is coming; his heart feels light and his mood is elevated. He dreamed Juliet kissed him back to life, making him feel like an emperor, and reflects that even dreams of love are joyful compared to real love. This hopeful mood sharply contrasts with the tragic news to come.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar says Juliet is well in spirit but her body lies in the Capulet tomb; he saw her buried and rode quickly to tell Romeo, apologizing for the bad news since Romeo asked him to report.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo immediately resolves to defy fate, asking for ink, paper, and post-horses to leave for Verona tonight, showing his rash decision to join Juliet in death.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar urges patience, noting Romeo’s pale and wild appearance suggests some disaster is imminent.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Balthasar’s concern, insists he is mistaken, and repeats his order to get horses, asking again about letters from the Friar.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar simply says he has no letters from the Friar.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says it doesn’t matter and sends Balthasar to hire horses, saying he will follow soon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo declares he will kill himself to lie with Juliet tonight, then recalls an apothecary he saw recently who looked poor and desperate, with a shop full of strange items, and thought then that such a man would sell poison despite the law.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo notes that his earlier observation foreshadowed his current need, and he identifies the apothecary’s shut shop, calling out to him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo offers forty ducats for a fast-acting poison that will spread through the veins and kill as quickly as a cannon firing.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the apothecary that since he is already suffering and the world’s laws don’t help him, he should break the law and take the money.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: Friar John calls out for Friar Lawrence, announcing his arrival.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence recognizes Friar John’s voice and immediately asks for news from Romeo or a letter from him.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: He explains that while searching for another friar to accompany him, the city health inspectors sealed them in a house under quarantine for plague, preventing his journey to Mantua.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urgently asks who delivered the letter to Romeo if Friar John could not.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: He replies that he could not send the letter or find a messenger because everyone was too afraid of infection.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He laments this unlucky event, stressing that the letter was not trivial but vitally important, and its neglect may cause great harm. He orders Friar John to fetch an iron crowbar immediately.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: He agrees to go and bring the crowbar.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Alone, he resolves to go to the tomb where Juliet will awaken in three hours. He fears she will blame him because Romeo was not informed, but he plans to write again and shelter her until Romeo arrives, calling her a poor living corpse enclosed in a dead man’s tomb.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris orders his page to take the torch and stand at a distance, then extinguish it to avoid being seen. He instructs the boy to lie flat under a yew tree with his ear to the ground to detect anyone approaching the graveyard, which is loose from recent grave-digging, and to whistle as a signal. He then takes the flowers and sends the page away.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris mourns Juliet, scattering flowers on her grave as a bridal bed, lamenting that her canopy is only dust and stones. He vows to perform nightly rituals of sprinkling the grave with sweet water or his own tears, keeping vigil with weeping. This speech establishes his devotion and heightens the tragic atmosphere.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo demands tools from Balthasar and gives him a letter for Montague. He orders Balthasar to leave with the torch and not interfere, explaining he is entering the tomb partly to see Juliet's face but mainly to retrieve a ring for important use. He threatens to dismember Balthasar if he stays, comparing his own savage intent to tigers or the sea.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar agrees to leave, showing his obedience but also foreshadowing his later actions.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo approves this as friendship, gives him money, and bids him farewell with wishes for prosperity.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Despite his promise, Balthasar resolves to hide nearby because he fears Romeo's looks and doubts his intentions, adding suspense.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses the tomb as a detestable stomach or womb of death, full of earth's dearest morsel (Juliet), and forces it open. In defiance, he says he will cram it with more food, meaning he plans to join Juliet in death.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris recognizes Romeo as the exiled Montague who killed Tybalt, which he believes caused Juliet's death. He accuses Romeo of coming to desecrate the bodies and decides to arrest him, demanding he stop his unhallowed work and submit to death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo admits he must die and came for that purpose. He urges Paris, whom he calls a gentle youth, not to provoke a desperate man but to flee and save himself. He insists he loves Paris more than himself because he is armed against himself, and begs him to leave so Romeo won't add another sin by killing him.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris rejects Romeo's plea, defying his urging to leave, and declares he arrests him as a felon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if Paris is provoking him and then attacks, initiating their fight.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris, dying, asks Romeo to open the tomb and lay him with Juliet, showing his enduring love and linking their fates.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to bury Paris, recognizing him as Mercutio's kinsman and recalling he was to marry Juliet. He calls Paris a fellow sufferer in misfortune and lays him in the monument. He then marvels at Juliet's beauty, which death hasn't dimmed, and questions if death is amorous and keeps her as a lover. Resolving to stay, he drinks poison and dies after a final kiss, seeking escape from life's sorrows.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence invokes Saint Francis for help and notes how often his feet have stumbled at graves tonight. He asks who is there with the dead so late, showing his unease and urgency.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar identifies himself as a friend who knows the Friar, revealing his presence and connection.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar blesses Balthasar and asks about a torch burning uselessly for grubs and skulls in the Capulet monument, noticing the ominous light and hinting at the tragedy within.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He confirms that Romeo is at the tomb and calls him his master, meaning he is Romeo’s servant.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He asks who is there, showing his surprise and concern.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He identifies Romeo as the person in the tomb.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He asks how long Romeo has been there, trying to gauge the urgency.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He says Romeo has been there for half an hour, indicating a significant delay.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges Balthasar to accompany him to the vault, showing his haste.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He refuses, explaining that Romeo threatened to kill him if he stayed to spy on his actions.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He decides to go alone, expressing a growing fear that something terrible has happened.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He recounts a dream in which he saw Romeo kill someone, foreshadowing the fight with Paris.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He discovers the bloody scene, questions the presence of swords, and finds Romeo and Paris dead. He then notices Juliet waking, adding to the tension.

speaker: JULIET
content: She wakes and immediately asks for Romeo, showing her disorientation and love.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges Juliet to flee, reveals that Romeo and Paris are dead, and offers to hide her in a nunnery, but he panics as the watch approaches.

speaker: JULIET
content: She refuses to leave, showing her resolve to stay with Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: She finds the poison vial, curses Romeo for drinking it all, kisses him hoping for residual poison, and upon hearing noise, stabs herself with his dagger.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He asks what the commotion in the streets is about, showing the family’s alarm.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She reports that people are shouting the names of Romeo, Juliet, and Paris, and running toward the family tomb, revealing the public discovery of the tragedy.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He exclaims in horror at Juliet's bleeding body, mistakenly thinking the dagger intended for Montague has instead pierced her chest. This reveals his immediate grief and misunderstanding of the situation.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She compares the sight of death to a funeral bell tolling for her own old age, expressing that this tragedy foreshadows her own demise.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He announces his wife has died from grief over Romeo's exile and fears what further sorrow awaits him, showing how the feud's consequences extend beyond the young lovers.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He addresses the dead Romeo, scolding him for the impropriety of dying before his father, revealing parental grief mixed with traditional expectations of familial order.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He admits he appears most guilty due to circumstances but stands ready to both accuse and clear himself, establishing his role as both witness and suspect.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He narrates the entire secret marriage, Juliet's fake death potion, the failed letter to Romeo, and the tragic suicides, accepting responsibility if he is at fault. This speech provides the crucial exposition that resolves the play's misunderstandings.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He explains he brought Juliet's death news to Romeo, accompanied him to the tomb, and was given a letter for Montague, corroborating the Friar's account of Romeo's actions.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He offers Montague his hand in reconciliation, calling this peace his daughter's marriage settlement, showing his grief has transformed into a desire for unity.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He promises to honor Juliet with a golden statue so renowned that no other in Verona will be as valued, demonstrating his acceptance of the Capulets and tribute to her fidelity.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He vows to build an equally rich statue for Romeo to lie beside Juliet's, calling them poor sacrifices to the families' feud, finally acknowledging their love and the tragedy's cause.
